aws::graph::propositions: # HYD2 Pulley Bearing Technical Analysis
The HYD2 pulley bearing has part number P/N 704A33-651-269.
The HYD2 pulley bearing has serial number S/N 15-15733.
The HYD2 pulley bearing is a double-row ball bearing.
The HYD2 pulley bearing was introduced onto the AS350-series helicopter via modification MOD 07-9568.
The HYD2 pulley bearing is composed of a single-piece, double-row inner ring.
The HYD2 pulley bearing is composed of two outer rings.
The HYD2 pulley bearing is composed of a single-piece cage.
The HYD2 pulley bearing is composed of 14 balls in each row.
The HYD2 pulley bearing has a total of 28 balls.
The HYD2 pulley bearing has bearing sealing flanges on both sides.
Bearing sealing flanges are also known as bearing shields.
Each bearing sealing flange contained four distinct locations with pre-drilled greasing holes.
The greasing holes are used to add grease to the bearing.
The retained HYD2 components were shipped to Airbus Helicopters' materials laboratory in Marignane, France for examination.
The hydraulic pump was able to be rotated by using its driveshaft after being removed from the pulley assembly.
The hydraulic pump showed no evidence of binding during rotation.
The hydraulic pump showed no evidence of restriction during rotation.
The pulley bearing's visible surfaces were thermally discolored.
The bearing was removed from the pulley.
Smearing damage was found within a 140° arc on the inner diameter of the pulley.
Residual grease was found on the inner diameter of the pulley.
The direction of the smearing damage was parallel to the bearing's rotational axis.
Longitudinal scratches were observed on the inner diameter of the bearing inner ring.
The longitudinal scratches were parallel to the bearing's rotational axis.
The bearing was disassembled for examination.
The bearing's inner ring exhibited a black-colored residue consistent with thermally degraded grease.
The bearing's outer rings exhibited a black-colored residue consistent with thermally degraded grease.
The bearing's cage exhibited a black-colored residue consistent with thermally degraded grease.
The bearing's rolling elements exhibited a black-colored residue consistent with thermally degraded grease.
After cleaning, the inner rings revealed plastic deformation.
After cleaning, the outer rings revealed plastic deformation.
After cleaning, the rolling elements revealed plastic deformation.
Cage material transfer was found on the raceways.
The cage showed evidence of abnormal contact damage between it and the rolling elements.
Hardness testing was performed on undamaged portions of the inner ring.
Hardness testing was performed on undamaged portions of the outer ring.
Hardness testing was performed on undamaged portions of the rolling elements.
The hardness testing revealed the inner ring met drawing requirements.
The hardness testing revealed the outer ring met drawing requirements.
The hardness testing revealed the rolling elements met drawing requirements.

text:
# The HYD2 Pulley Bearing

The HYD2 pulley bearing, part number (P/N) 704A33-651-269 and serial number (S/N) 15-15733, was a double-row ball bearing that was introduced onto the AS350-series helicopter via modification (MOD) 07-9568. The bearing is composed of a single-piece, double-row inner ring; two outer rings; a single-piece cage; and 14 balls (spherical rolling elements) in each row for a total of 28 balls. Bearing sealing flanges, also known as a bearing shield, covered the roller elements and its cage on both sides of the bearing for a total of two sealing flanges per bearing. Each bearing sealing flange contained four distinct locations with pre-drilled greasing holes, to be used to add grease to the bearing.

The retained HYD2 components were shipped to Airbus Helicopters' materials laboratory in Marignane, France for examination. The hydraulic pump, once removed from the pulley assembly, was able to be rotated by using its driveshaft, with no evidence of binding or restriction during rotation. The pulley bearing's visible surfaces were thermally discolored. The bearing was removed from the pulley, revealing smearing damage found within a 140° arc on the inner diameter of the pulley, along with residual grease (see Figure 1). The direction of the smearing damage was parallel to the bearing's rotational axis. Additionally, longitudinal scratches, also parallel to the bearing's rotational axis, was observed on the inner diameter of the bearing inner ring. The bearing was disassembled and its inner ring, outer rings, cage, and rolling elements exhibited a black-colored residue consistent with thermally degraded grease (see Figure 2). After cleaning the inner and outer rings and the rolling elements, examination of their surfaces revealed plastic deformation as well as cage material transfer on the raceways. The cage showed evidence of abnormal contact damage between it and the rolling elements. Hardness testing of the undamaged portions of the inner ring, outer ring, and rolling elements revealed they met drawing requirements.

---
